intro: Pachystele, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a rare and unique plant native to the arid regions of Southwestern Australia. It is characterized by its striking, waxy, white or pale blue flowers that resemble ghostly apparitions, hence its common name. The plant has a thick, fleshy stem and leaves that are adapted to store water, allowing it to survive in harsh, dry environments. It blooms during the cooler months, typically from June to August, and relies on specific pollinators for reproduction. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, the pachystele is considered a vulnerable species.
